I agree. However, for those tests to be interesting, given that there's no way (especially in a bounded Pipeline) to produce reliable speculative/late panes, we need a source capable of producing late data/partial bundles. I expect that most of these code paths will be exercised in new Direct Runner tests given a clock-controlling source.

I now remember what feature I really wanted, and it is available as of 3.2.1: Being able to explicitly exclude build of a project in the Reactor, since dependency exclusions don't work there.

So anyone using an OS that is still < 3.2 is probably used to having to install their own software, and it won't be too great a burden.

This is currently being used by Dataflow to validate that the output path for file based sinks is a valid GCS location, you can't remove it without removing a good error catching signal for users.

What was the motivation behind this change?
@kennknowles This is an example of a piece of data about a read operation which a runner is interested in looking at to provide a better experience for users.

I believe that the precondition was only necessary for native sinks. Now
that we're all Java sources here I don't see why a Dataflow job couldn't
write to s3.
On Fri, Jul 15, 2016 at 06:26 lukecwik notifications@github.com wrote:

> @kennknowles https://github.com/kennknowles This is an example of a
> piece of data about a read operation which a runner is interested in
> looking at to provide a better experience for users.
> 
> 
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/pull/656#issuecomment-232950196,
> or mute the thread
> https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAgIT0sVec3ANaP7QV9SE9b3EVqALflkks5qV4qLgaJpZM4JMqMg
> .

This was a feature we had part of the Dataflow runner for native sinks. During the migration from native sinks to custom sinks, we wanted to maintain that feature. We could remove the feature now but that would mean that mistyped paths would only be validated during execution of the pipeline vs at construction time.

I think this all ties into what do we do with IOChannelUtils in the longer run and who is responsible for validation (SDK, Runner, both?).

Typically when we change `pom.xml` to have new dependencies we need to have a discussion about dependencies & licensing.
- What new dependencies are added?
- Are they quality and stable enough to depend on?
- Are they public or private deps; should they be shaded?
- Do they all (and all transitive deps) have appropriate licenses?

@bjchambers : Did you have that discussion off-thread and, if not, can we verify that we're doing the right thing in all places?

RE: PR context, I noticed in the [coveralls build list](https://coveralls.io/repos/101216/builds), all PR's from jenkins are listed as #99999. IIRC, this is some hack @davorbonaci needed to add to make it work. The [build for this PR from travis](https://coveralls.io/builds/6931744) has its PR number correct.

Not sure if there are other pros- and cons- of collecting from Travis vs Jenkins. @jasonkuster, do you know?
I went through the avro 1.7.7 spec and avro 1.8.1 spec and deduced that 1.8.1 is backwards compatible for their encoded format.

R: @kennknowles
Thanks Robert. Closing pull request.

I've added a Dynamic Sharding override instead of the random number of fixed shards. This uses the log base 10 of the number of records to determine the number of shards, with a minimum of three shards (with the exception of 1 or 2 records).

Thanks for digging into this!

Changes Unknown when pulling **2efe7617a595b8ac6167db40724d9874afd6df23 on francesperry:master** into *\* on apache:master**.

Drive-by observations:
1) In case it turns out impractical to implement estimated size, progress computation, or dynamic splitting for Mongo, then you don't need the BoundedSource API and can implement the source as a simple ParDo. This still holds even if you support splitIntoBundles: it can be a separate ParDo with a fusion break in between. BoundedSource is only useful if you actually use its magical operations that ParDo's can't do, otherwise it's more difficult to develop against.
2) It may or may not be a good idea to add another fusion break after the read (e.g. a reshuffle), so that even though the reading happens in sequence, the processing would be parallel.
That seems reasonable.

Thanks for the feedback @jkff. Good point for BoundedSource vs ParDo. My purpose is to implement the BoundedSource feature. I'm experimenting different solutions. If it's not really possible, than I will refactore the MongDbIO Read to use ParDo internally instead of BoundedSource.
superseded by #651
